page.title: 07Welbeck Pit in the 1950/60s
page.content: In the 1950s there were many changes to Mr. Moody's job as a miner at Welbeck Colliery.Hydraulic props were introduced and the introduction of other machinery meant that 95% of all coal was being loaded by machines.This was slow but it meant that 50% more coal could be turned in 24 hours.There were also more breakdowns. The pit held three world records for deep mined coal output during this period,the records being held for several months at a time. Eventually,the rundown in the mining industry in the 1960s led to a lot of job-losses,many pit closures and a standstill in wages.Many men left the pit for better paid,cleaner and safer jobs outside the industry,and Welbeck took on a lot of "Geordie" miners,who came from "worked out" pits in the North-East.
